message: For what it's worth, I think that saying that the MC doesn't need a goal is as heretical a thought as saying the MC doesn't have to change, and I give kudos to Chris and Melanie for teasing that out.

That said, the MC Problem or MC Solution, MC Issue, MC Domain, etc. can seem like goals too, in the right context.
It is far more nuanced and flexible.
Yes, and the big push now is to make sure the "Hero" has "Wants" and "Needs"
I'm not following.

To follow up on your Judgment: Bad question, there are those stories where the MC's Change or Steadfast disposition directly correlates to the personal outcome of Good and Bad, and there are those stories where there is no correlation whatsoever.  For instance, if Luke Skywalker hadn't changed, it would have been more of a "Bad" ending.  But in "Drag Me to Hell", the girl changes in the appropriate way but it still ends up very badly.  You can also say the same about the correlation between Success/Failure and Good/Bad, in that sometimes the two dynamics are directly tied together (e.g. "Success" is inevitably tied to "Good"), sometimes they are inversely related (e.g. "Success" necessarily leads to "Bad"), sometimes they have no correlation whatsoever, and sometimes they "influence" the other on some gray scale.  It all depends on the story!
